pageData.text: This investigation is a chemical engineering challenge. The task is to investigate a less expensive and less toxic chemical air bag system for the automobile industry. An air bag restraint system will be modeled through a series of steps. First, the quantity in moles of carbon dioxide required to fill a model air bag at room temperature and pressure will be determined using the <button className='glossary-text'>Ideal Gas Law</button>. Second, the amounts of sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid reactants required to produce a sufficient volume of carbon dioxide to fill the model air bag without bursting it will be calculated. Third, the reaction will be performed to test the inflation of the prototype model air bag with the predicted reactants. The final step involves scale-up and calculation of the reactant quantities required to produce enough carbon dioxide to fill driver-side and passenger-side air bags at room temperature and pressure.

pageData.desc: Preparation 10 minutes, Activity 1: Stoichiometry of Reactants and Products 20 minutes, Activity 2: Testing Model Air Bags 30 minutes, Activity 3: Amount of CO2 for Full-Size Air Bags 10 minutes

Apply the <button className='glossary-text'>Ideal Gas Law</button> to calculate the moles of CO<sub>2</sub> produced in a reaction.
Calculate the stoichiometric amounts of reactants required to produce a specific quantity of product.
Assess reactant amounts by mixing and observing the inflation of the model air bag.

pageData.text: When someone thinks of an airbag, they may immediately think of the device found in cars. However, this is not the only application they have. Avalanches can quickly create a life-threatening situation for skiers as massive amounts of snow comes barreling down a mountain. If a skier is caught in this, chances are they will become buried under snow. Rescuers describe the way a skier is buried as either critical or non-critical. A critical burial occurs when the head and oral cavity are buried under snow. The mortality rate for critical burials is ten times higher when compared to non-critical burials<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Avalanche airbags are meant to increase the chances of survival from critical burials by creating an air pocket for victims to allow easier access to the air available to them. They do this by inflating during the avalanche, then after three minutes they deflate to create an air pocket. Researchers discovered that airbag-created air pockets create an environment that would maintain normal physiology for sixty minutes<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. These minutes are certainly valuable to the victims and the rescuers searching for them in the aftermath.

1McIntosh, S., Polukoff, N., Little, C., Seibert, T., & Grissom, C. (2020, September 21). Avalanche airbags: Latest research. The Avalanche Review.
https://theavalanchereview.org/avalanche-airbag-research/

pageData.desc: Snow falling down a mountain in an avalanche.
pageData.altText: Snow falling down a mountain in an avalanche.

pageData.text: This lab illustrates how stoichiometry and the can be used to predict the moles of gas needed to fill a model of an automobile air bag and how to scale up to predict the number of moles needed to fill full-size air bags. is the quantitative study of a chemical reaction and is based upon the coefficients of a balanced chemical equation. Coefficients represent the molar ratios of reactants to products. These ratios predict the number of moles of reactant needed to produce a given number of moles of product. These molar amounts can be converted into grams for solids or into liters for gases at given temperatures and pressures.

options.text: the quantitative study of wavelengths of light
the qualitative study of the products produced by chemical reactions
the quantitative study of a chemical reaction based on coefficients of a balanced chemical equation
the study of the types of bonds between atoms
the qualitative study of gas molecules based on chemical reactions in a closed system

Coefficients predict the molar amounts of reactants and products.

These ratios predict the number of moles of reactant needed to produce a given number of moles of product. These molar amounts can be converted into grams for solids or into liters for gases at given temperatures and pressures.

pageData.text: The <button className='glossary-text'>Ideal Gas Law</button> shows the relationship of all four variables for gases in one equation. That equation is PV = nRT, where P represents pressure (in atmospheres [atm]), V represents volume (in liters), n represents the number of moles, R represents the gas law constant (0.0821 L-atm/mole·K), and T represents temperature (in degrees Kelvin).

pageData.question: How is the Ideal Gas Law useful?

options.text: It shows the relationship between four variables for gases in one equation.
It shows the relationship between ideal gases and real gases.
It predicts the number of moles of reactant needed to produce a given number of moles of product.
It represents the molar ratios of reactants to products in a balanced chemical equation.
It shows the relationship between coefficients and molar ratios.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The Ideal Gas Law shows the relationship of all four variables for gases in one equation.

pageData.question: If the Ideal Gas Law shows the relationship between four variables for gases, why does it have 5 variables in its equation PV=nRT?

options.text: P is not a variable but the gas law constant.
V is not a variable but the gas law constant.
n is not a variable but the gas law constant.
R is not a variable but the gas law constant.
T is not a variable but the gas law constant.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: R represents the gas law constant (0.0821 L-atm/ mole·K).

pageData.text: Air bags in automobiles activate when an accelerometer in a microchip senses an impact force equivalent to hitting a wall at a speed of 10–15 miles per hour. The accelerometer closes a switch that ignites a charge, causing a pellet of sodium azide (NaN3) to explode. This explosion releases sodium metal and harmless nitrogen gas that inflate the bag. The reaction is shown in the following equation:2NaN3(s) ➝ 2Na(s) + 3N2(g)The sodium metal produced is highly reactive and will react violently with water. Therefore, iron oxide (Fe2O3) is placed in the compartment along with the sodium azide. The sodium metal produced by the inflation reaction in turn reacts with the iron oxide to produce harmless sodium oxide (Na2O) and iron (Fe). Talcum powder or cornstarch is also released during the inflation. These substances keep the air bag pliable and lubricated during storage.

Sodium azide is very toxic. The fate of this compound when it is left in junked cars is a significant environmental concern. Because of sodium azide’s potential to harm the environment, manufacturers are searching for safer, “greener” reactant chemicals for air bag inflation. This lab investigates the nontoxic reaction of sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid to produce carbon dioxide gas and a harmless salt, sodium acetate.

pageData.question: What is the role of iron oxide (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) in automobile airbags?

options.text: It keeps the airbag pliable during storage.
It reacts with sodium metal byproduct to prevent a violent sodium-water reaction.
It explodes, producing nitrogen gas that inflates the airbag.
It catalyzes the reaction in the airbag.
It reacts with sodium azide (NaN<sub>3</sub>) to produce nitrogen gas that inflates the airbag.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: An impact force triggers the explosion of sodium azide (NaN<sub>3</sub>), which produces nitrogen gas that inflates the airbag. It also produces sodium metal, which reacts violently with water. To prevent this, iron oxide (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) is added to airbags to react with the sodium metal to produce harmless byproducts.

pageData.question: What is the role of sodium azide (NaN<sub>3</sub>) in automobile airbags?

options.text: It explodes during deployment, releasing nitrogen gas that inflates the bag.
Because of its toxic nature, sodium azide is no longer used in modern airbags.
It keeps the airbag pliable during deployment.
It keeps the airbag lubricated during storage.
It neutralizes the harmful nitrogen gas released by the chemical reaction during deployment.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: During deployment a pellet of sodium azide (NaN<sub>3</sub>) explodes. This explosion releases sodium metal and harmless nitrogen gas that inflate the bag.

The accelerometer closes a switch that ignites a charge, causing a pellet of sodium azide (NaN<sub>3</sub>) to explode. This explosion releases sodium metal and harmless nitrogen gas that inflate the bag. The sodium metal produced is highly reactive and will react violently with water. Therefore, iron oxide (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) is placed in the compartment along with the sodium azide. The sodium metal produced by the inflation reaction in turn reacts with the iron oxide to produce harmless sodium oxide (Na<sub>2</sub>O) and iron (Fe).

The sodium metal produced by the inflation reaction in turn reacts with the iron oxide to produce harmless sodium oxide (Na<sub>2</sub>O) and iron (Fe).

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. You will start activity 1 by calculating the moles of carbon dioxide required to fill a resealable bag. Next, determine the balanced equation for the sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid reaction. Then, calculate the grams of sodium bicarbonate and volume of acetic acid needed to produce the moles of carbon dioxide required to fill the bag. In activity 2, begin by measuring out sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid. Next, combine the reactants in a resealable bag. Repeat this process for three total trials, then compare inflated bags. In activity 3, for each story problem, start by calculating the moles of carbon dioxide needed to fill the air bag. Next, calculate the grams of sodium bicarbonate needed for the reaction. Then, calculate the volume of acetic acid needed for the reaction.

In activity 2, begin by measuring out sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid. Next, combine the reactants in a resealable bag. Repeat this process for three total trials, then compare inflated bags. In activity 3, for each story problem, start by calculating the moles of carbon dioxide needed to fill the air bag. Next, calculate the grams of sodium bicarbonate needed for the reaction. Then, calculate the volume of acetic acid needed for the reaction.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure sections.The vinegar and baking soda are not suitable for household consumption or use. They should be considered chemicals and kept away from children and pets.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

In Activity 1, you will calculate the exact stoichiometric amounts of sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid that will react to completely fill a sealed bag without bursting it. You will test these amounts in Activity 2.

pages.title:
A
  Stoichiometry of Reactants and Products (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Stoichiometry of Reactants and Products (9 steps)

typeBefore.text: Simulate air bag deployment by mixing reactants to fill a resealable plastic bag with carbon dioxide gas. The goal is to determine the exact stoichiometric amounts of sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid that will react to completely fill a sealed bag without bursting it.

pageData.text: The volume of each 6 × 9-inch resealable bag is 1.20 liters.
The current air pressure in inches of mercury can be found on local weather reports or by an internet search using the keywords, “air pressure for XXXXX” (where XXXXX is the local zip code).

Convert the air pressure from inches of mercury to the nearest 0.01 atmospheres using the following conversion (and record in Data Table 1):_____ inches x 25.4 mm/1.00 inch x 1.00 atm/760. mm = _____ atm
Measure the room temperature in °C with a thermometer. Convert to Kelvin by adding 273, and record in Data Table 1 as Kelvin temperature.
Use the to calculate the number of moles (n) of carbon dioxide required to fill a 6 × 9-inch bag. Record the number of moles (n) in Data Table 1.n = PV/RT

Examine the reaction of the weak base, sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), and the weak acid found in vinegar, acetic acid (CH3COOH). The products are the aqueous salt, sodium acetate (CH3COONa), and carbonic acid (H2CO3), an intermediate compound. This quickly breaks down into water and carbon dioxide, as shown in the following equation in bold print:
1. NaHCO3(s) + CH3COOH(aq) ➝ 2. H2CO3(aq) + CH3COONa(aq) ➝ 3. H2O(l) + CO2(g) + CH3COONa(aq)
In Data Table 1, write a balanced equation for only the reactants and products in bold print shown above in lines 1 and 3. Line 1 are the reactants and line 3 are the products.

Beginning with the moles of carbon dioxide determined in step 5 and the balanced chemical equation, calculate the grams of sodium bicarbonate reactant [MW = 84.0 g/ mol] needed to produce this number of moles of carbon dioxide. Record your results in Data Table 1.grams = 84.0 g/molHCO3 x molCO2 x molar ratio HCO3 : CO2molar ratio HCO3 : CO2 = stoichiometric coefficient HCO3/stoichiometric coefficient CO2

The source of acetic acid is a solution of vinegar, which is 0.833 M acetic acid. Beginning with the number of moles of carbon dioxide determined in step 5 and the balanced chemical equation, calculate the volume of vinegar solution required. Record your results in Data Table 1.volume mL = (molCO2 x molar ratio CH3COOH : CO2)/(0.833 mol/1 L) x 1000 mL/1 L

In Activity 2, you will fill resealable bags with sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid according to the calculations performed in Activity 1. You will also test increased amounts of these reactants and compare the volume and speed of inflation of the simulated air bags.

pages.title:
A
  Testing Model Air Bags (11 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Testing Model Air Bags (11 steps)

pageData.text: Using the balance and a weigh boat, weigh the grams of sodium bicarbonate that was calculated in step 8 of Activity 1. Record exact mass in Data Table 2.
Using the 50 mL graduated cylinder, measure out the volume of vinegar that was calculated in step 9 of Activity 1.
Open a 6 x 9-inch resealable bag and hold it upright with the narrower 6-inch end over the edge of the 250-mL beaker. This should create a peak and two valleys in the bag. See Figure 1.

In the valley outside of the beaker, add the sodium bicarbonate powder. After adding the powder, hold the portion of the bag containing the powder tightly against the outside of the beaker. This will help prevent a premature reaction in the next steps.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. Diagram of bag setup as described in Activity 2 steps 3 through 7.
pageData.altText: Figure 1. Diagram of bag setup as described in Activity 2 steps 3 through 7.

pageData.text: Pour the vinegar into the other valley. Take care not to mix the two reactants before sealing the bag.
Carefully remove all the excess air from the bag and seal the bag. The bag must be sealed completely to avoid losing any gas during the reaction.
Pick up the bag and tilt it so that the vinegar flows over the sodium bicarbonate and begins to react.
Hold the bag by the top seal and shake the bag to mix all the reactants. The reaction should look similar to Figure 2.
The reaction is complete when there is only a clear solution left. Leave the bag inflated for comparing to the bags in the next two steps. Record all data and observations in Data Table 2.

Repeat the experiment using a fresh, clean bag. Increase the amount of sodium bicarbonate by an additional 0.3 g and the vinegar by an additional 5 mL. Record exact mass of sodium bicarbonate in Data Table 2. Observe and compare how quickly and how much more the bag inflates.

pageData.desc: Figure 2. photo showing sample reaction within plastic bag in progress
pageData.altText: Figure 2. photo showing sample reaction within plastic bag in progress

pageData.text: Repeat the experiment a third time using a fresh, clean bag. Increase the amount of sodium bicarbonate over the original amount by an additional 0.5 g and the vinegar by an additional 10 mL. Record exact mass of sodium bicarbonate in Data Table 2. Observe and compare how quickly and how much more the bag inflates.
Activity 3 is intended as an extension activity and requires the application of concepts from the Background and previous activities to solve a mathematical problem.

pages.title:
A

pages.pageTitle:
A
  Amount of CO2 for Full-Size Air Bags (2 steps)

typeBefore.text: The following activity is intended as an extension activity and requires the application of concepts from the Background and previous activities to solve a mathematical problem.

pageData.text: The volume of a driver-side air bag is 80.0 L. Calculate the number of moles of CO<sub>2</sub> needed to fill the air bag and the grams of sodium bicarbonate and milliliters of vinegar needed for the reaction. Take a photo of your calculations and include it in your lab notebook.

The volume of a passenger-side air bag is 160.0 L. Calculate the number of moles of CO<sub>2</sub> needed to inflate the air bag and the grams of sodium bicarbonate and milliliters of vinegar needed for the reaction. Take a photo of your calculations and include it in your lab notebook.

text: Dispose of plastic bags, plastic spoon, and weighing boat.
Rinse graduated cylinder, dry with paper towel, and return to equipment kit.
Leftover baking soda and vinegar should be returned to the chemical kit.

text: Based upon the observed performance of the air bag models and the amounts of sodium bicarbonate and acetic acid (vinegar) needed for an automotive air bag of 80 or 160 L, are these reactants a good substitute for sodium azide? One additional note regarding sodium azide: the rate of inflation after a triggering impact is 40 milliseconds (0.04 s).
